column1: As the parasitic seedling gets closer to the host plant
column2: it will experience the shading effect of the host plant's leaves blocking out sunlight. Whilst the parasitic plant does not have eyes
column3: it does have specialized proteins called phytochromes that allow the plant to "see" different types of light
column4: and to determine if it is in full sunlight or in shaded conditions. This helps the parasite to prepare for host contact and invasion.Finally
column5: the parasite will make contact with a host plant and experience "touch." Many plants respond to touch. For most plants
column7: touch is associated with danger. Touch could indicate to a plant that insects are landing on its leaves and trying to eat them. In this case
column8: plants use touch to stop growth and instead spend their valuable energy resources on defense. These plants make a range of toxic chemicals that will stop insects from feeding on them. Some plants also use touch to trigger a strengthening of the leaf cell walls
column9: making it harder for the insects to eat them. For Cuscuta parasites
column11: telling the parasite that it has made contact with a potential host plant.
